Posts.Content: May 29, 2015 05:41AM intothewoods wrote: Stefajoy, I'm still confused too and I'm like RonnieKay- a tell all type. I used the word metastatic BC and people don't really understand what that is. I'm still hesitant to say stage iv and when I do I get the weird-y response or the "I didn't know you were stage iv" so maybe saying stage iv from get go would have been better. It's difficult for people to understand when you are still looking fine and feeling ok. Especially if you are the type to minimize things (which is part of what got me here but that's another story) I want it both ways- support and understanding and not being the downer. There may be no right decision- just managing the one you make. take care, Lisa

Posts.Title: So I am riding the ANXIETY Bus right now... Fitztwins

Posts.Content: May 18, 2015 07:37AM intothewoods wrote: Hi terrij, I'm 15 mos out and ditto what Nel eloquently stated. It isn't easy- it's different and you may be surprised to find that in time the "different" is in some ways a positive. The vast majority of my days are normal with the occasional days when I feel more down, fearful and uncertain. Then I remember the things that bring me peace and a sense of control, the most important of which is practicing gratitude and remembering I am a long way off from death. You might find some inspiration from the "Life does not end with a stage iv diagnosis thread." I also suggest you talk with your doctor about having some ativan on hand (I use for sleep occasionally) and or an antidepressant that relieves anxiety such as zoloft or effexor. This whole damn thing is a process; trust that you will find coping strategies that will work well for you. Best to you!

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2014 07:06PM intothewoods wrote: Ladies, thank you so much!  I really appreciate your input. Susan, I got a good laugh out of your post.  Acronyms! They can be so tricky.   Brenda,  I will ask about a cardiac assessment. My skin recurrence was on the left side so I would think that would be a relevant question. As far as exercise goes, I have worked throughout the radiation and didn't exercise at all. I  practice yoga at home in addition to walking my dog. (we actually walk- not a leisurely sniff-fest) I can tolerate the yoga because I can do it topless at home. I did some this morning for the first time in 7 weeks. I'm avoiding any other exercise  until my skin heals.  Thank- you again! I am ready for my appt. Lisa
Posts.Title: 1st F/U appt with M.O.- questions? intothewoods intothewoods

Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2014 06:08PM intothewoods wrote: Brenda, Caryn and Pajim thank you again. The visit went well (although even though I had the questions written down I did forget to follow up on one of them) We will do a restaging CT in mid August of the chest, abdomen and pelvis. (the whole staging thing is still a bit of a mystery. My current understanding is that from a medical and statistical perspective I am Stage 1 with metastatic disease so I don't get why they refer to it as restaging.) He likes to use both CT and bone scans and will do a bone scan 4 months after the August CT scan and then scan every 4 months for a while then every 6 months. He is very confident in the letrozole and that is what I neglected to follow up on- what if it fails (I'll email  him.) He's not wanting to do a bisphosphonate at this time due to the SE and given that I don't have any of the rib discomfort I was feeling and with just the one met to the rib. Regarding the cardiac assessment he said "we don't do that because any cardiac problems arising from the radiation would surface 40-45 years out"  to which I replied, "From your lips to god's ear that I should be alive then." Even without metastatic disease. (I will be 97 in 40 years. Notice the will be. Ya never know.) Lisa

Posts.Title: OT (slightly) Beautiful Gestures intothewoods intothewoods

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2015 09:09AM intothewoods wrote: Hello everyone and best wishes for a beautiful 2016! I've been doing some lurking every so often but not posting until now. I'm so happy for this thread, LynnFish and all the great info! Very timely for me as I am struggling with not enjoying work anymore and always feeling exhausted. Faslodex is doing the trick for me- no evidence of active disease on scan in September, Now I wonder constantly about what's best for me: work on reconnecting to what is good about my work, taking an early retirement, (just celebrated my 59th BD) going on disability first even though I don't feel disabled other than tiredness and cognition being "different" I know I freaked out my spouse and our financial advisor out when I said my job "is killing me." I wasn't even aware of what I had said. There's so much to sort out- Can I afford to retire? Can I afford not to? How long will savings last? What about health coverage? It feels almost more overwhelming than the cancer so thanks again for all the info. I'll be rereading this thread! Peace to all of you ladies! Lisa
Posts.Title: Financial and Career Implications of Cancer LynnFish Lumpie

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2015 05:15PM intothewoods wrote: Maybe I set a record for stopping a treatment :-) As far as insurance goes, I'm in California and have Kaiser HMO. I'm sure my co-pay will be higher for the Ibrance; it was for the afinitor. Hopefully the Ibrance is not too much. I don't have it yet as it needs to be ordered. Some people had a poor experience with Kaiser early on but I have been very happy with it. If you have a catastrophic illness it can be a very good place. There was a guy in my support group who needed a specialized type of stem cell transplant. Kaiser doesn't do that and refers out to City of Hope but my friend advocated for the real expertise in the area which was at Stanford. Kaiser paid for my friend's entire cost: lodging and airfare for several consultations, lodging for 6 mos after the transplant and a per diem for a 24 hr caregiver. Jobur, thanks for the Little Prince mention. I am barely managing work and the only reason I can I think is due to amazing support at home and not having children. I am constantly amazed at my colleagues who do the work with young kids. Thanks for the good wishes everyone. I'll keep you posted on the Ibrance thread. Lisa

Posts.Content: May 26, 2014 10:29PM intothewoods wrote: Had to smile at the "need to be able to get off the couch first" line Nel! So true! Yoga helps me tremendously but I must have my Effexor first! I was given Zoloft about 9 years ago for anxiety. I was told it was a good antidepressant for anxiety and it changed my life. Couldn't stay on Zoloft when I started tamoxifen so switched to Effexor. Went off of Effexor in Sept of 2012 when I finished the tamoxifen because I had had enough of drugs. Big mistake.  Went back on last September and I can't imagine how I'd be newly diagnosed with mets without it. Also have had Ativan on hand as needed for sleep.

I'm dealing with a lot of that lately with both of my sisters. I should have said something to my closest sister who recently asked me to call our uncle to inquire about something she wanted to know but I didn't think was necessary. When I hesitated she responded with, "oh yea, you have cancer." Even though I know my cancer is scary for her too (partly due to sibling nonsense) it still really bugged me.  Sending you hugs, Lisa

Posts.Title: How are people with liver mets doing? blondie1 JFL

Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2017 01:51PM intothewoods wrote: Good news to share! After 9 cycles of doxil and cytoxan my onc said I have had a complete response. There is no metabolic activity in my liver. My bony skeleton shows "intense diffuse activity... suggestive of effects of CSF (filgristim). Evaluation for osseous metastasis is limited in this setting." I say no bone mets :-) On prior visits onc said no more hormonals, which I had planned to negotiate after a year of chemo. Since I was getting close to the max for the doxil I was expecting to choose either taxol or xeloda. Onc left me in room for quite awhile as he wanted to show the scan to someone (I assume another onc) Much to my surprise he comes back in and says we're going to do femara and Ibrance. I was on femara when mets first discovered in 2014 then progressed. We tried Ibrance in 2015 with faslodex but stopped because even at 75 mg my WBC tanked. That was before the liver mets though so now we'll try neupogen to deal with the WBC. I'm adding in flax, green tea and lots of protein. I'm concerned about the low dose of Ibrance and I'm being lazy and ask all of you rather than research myself what the difference is between Neupogen and filgristim. Even if the Ibrance/femara doesn't work I am happy to get whatever break from chemo I can. There is so much activity and support on this thread! I do read some and send positive thoughts to all who are on new protocols or trying to make these tough decisions. Love to all Lisa
Posts.Title: How are people with liver mets doing? blondie1 JFL

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2018 01:26PM intothewoods wrote: Lisajo, I mostly read this thread but don't post. It was my first chemo.Wishing you all the best. Lisa

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2018 01:35PM intothewoods wrote: Hello everyone, I don't post here much but would love some of all ya'lls wisdom on what my oncologist wants to do. I've been on Taxotere since Sept 2017. It was working well at first- good scans and tumor markers decreasing. The last few months the tumor markers have been rising; the scan in Feb showed "no convincing evidence of progression" so he wanted to get a few more treatments in before considering any change I have been with my oncologist since 2007. I like him a lot, and know him to be super smart, very caring and aggressive in approach to treatment. I didn't go along with his aggressive approach when I was first diagnosed but now that I am metastatic I'm in. I think. I met with him yesterday and we are testing the marker again next Monday. If they have gone up he wants to add Xeloda and docetaxol! He knows it may affect my QOL and if so we would stop. He is looking for a complete response like I had with Doxil and Cytoxan. At this point I am somewhat reluctantly agreeing to give it a try. I would so appreciate any input anyone has. One question I have for him is if we do some Xeloda in combo can we use it later as a single agent. Gratefully, Lisa

I like and trust my onc very much I've been with him from first diagnosis in 2007 and he will work with me. He's currently out of town and I will be traveling too after Christmas. I have another treatment a few days after I return which I'll do and then we'll have a pow-wow. I'm retiring sometime in 2017 and won't start another school year so the chemo-brain won't be such an issue. I'll ask for Best Birds guide again. Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2016 01:06PM intothewoods wrote: Hello all I just read back a few pages and I'm encouraged by the caring, warmth and incredible wisdom shared and feel comfort knowing your support is here for me. I was recently diagnosed with mets in both lobes and more bone mets. I had my 2nd round of Doxil and Cytoxan Thursday and I'm seeing my onc today after email conversations in which he seemed to indicate he would keep me on this regime if it works as long as it's working. Originally he mentioned a "brief course of chemo" and then go back to Faslodex this time with Ibrance (I did try the Ibrance but we stopped due to low WBC) Has anyone else stayed with chemo until progression ? Going back to faslodex does seem questionable since I progressed on it. Any thoughts appreciated. Thanks to Stephanie and others for the gentle reminders to stay present. Lisa

Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2017 11:14AM intothewoods wrote: Z and JFL- thank you so much for the input! I have also heard that some time on chemo can re-sensitize to hormonals; I heard after a year so was so pleased to try it sooner. I'll ask about the ribociclib and why the letrozole rather than faslodex. I progressed on both so is it a timing thing? I was most recently on the faslodex. As far as the triplet trial with the A/A combo goes, I didn't put it in my signature but I briefly tried A/A before the liver mets appeared. We stopped it rather quickly because I broke out in a nasty rash and since I'm still working (not for much longer) I didn't want to scare the kids. Or parents. (I'm an elementary principal). However, I'm certainly willing to give it another try especially since I will be on summer break soon and may not go back to work. The retirement thing is complicated due to health insurance. Thanks again for such great information! Z. on another note I may join your fitbit community because I'm putting on pounds. Did I read in another thread that you do a 12 pose yoga sequence every morning? I do from 10-20 minutes most mornings and I'm curious about your sequence. Best to all Lisa
Posts.Title: How are people with liver mets doing? blondie1 JFL

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2018 10:07PM intothewoods wrote: Hello everyone, I do more lurking/brief pop-in than posting but want to chime in on hair loss. I wasn't as upset about the hair loss as I imagined. Can't say why though. Maybe just getting older or having an amazing partner who never wanted me to reconstruct (I never did either) and likes me bald. When my hair really started to shed and thin I had my hairdresser shave it. I have a hand tied wig that is very light and I like it. The only way I don't feel like a cancer patient is when I wear a wig. Forget turbans or scarves they make me feel the worst. I'd love to go out bald but I'm not there yet. For sure I would need to have a closer shave because not all my hair came out and what is left grows a little and I tend to look like the Peanuts character, Linus. On the upside, I needed to pay more attention to my brows and now that I have very little left and have to draw them in they actually look better. I miss my eyelashes a lot though. Thank you all for being you. Even though you may not know it, you give hope and support to women you don't interact with. Wishing all much love and light and good days.

Posts.Content: May 23, 2015 12:57PM intothewoods wrote: HLB, I hear you! Getting the afinitor is a multistep process for me. I can't mail order it like I do all the others. I get a two week supply at a time (just to start I hope!) and need blood work reviewed before they will give me more. Then I call the oncology pharmacist directly. Glad they are watchful but quite the to do! Hope yours arrives soon and that we both tolerate it well. I often think we hear from ladies who have a hard time and not so much from those who do well. Lisa

Posts.Title: How are people with liver mets doing? blondie1 JFL

Posts.Content: Dec 23, 2016 02:04PM intothewoods wrote: Livin, I hope your scan brings good results! zarokva congrats! I should be happy too since my recent scan results after starting chemo are stable to slightly improved but I need some encouragement and maybe advice. My onc wants me to continue on doxil and cytoxan until it's not working or doxil becomes toxic. I've had 6 cycles- every three weeks. With each cycle my dyspepsia lasts longer. Prilosec has helped a bit with the severity but I'm having more days of symptoms. Onc said to try twice a day for 10 days but I stopped around day 7 because it didn't seem to help. I miss Faslodex. I know some return to a hormonal and I hope to be able to do that too but for now the chemo has me down. And I feel like a whiner because dyspepsia is my only side-effect other than some fatigue and chemo brain which is fairly significant and impacting my work. any words of wisdom appreciated Lisa

Posts.Title: How are people with liver mets doing? blondie1 JFL

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2018 12:26PM intothewoods wrote: bstein, I took an 8 week Mindfulness Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) course. A mindfulness meditation pracitce has been helpful. Yoga is a part of the program. I hope you find your program to be helpful. I think you will. :-) lisajo, chiming in late here but I also found doxil to be a very easy chemo. My biggest issue was acid reflux and fatique. Prilosec helped. Also I didn't lose my hair but I was on a low dose. My onc said I wouldn't, the nurses said I would. I bought a wig just in case. I was still working at the time and only took a day or two off each cycle. To all of the ladies on this thread struggling with progression and new treatments know that I (and likely other lurker/occasional posters) follow your stories, think of you, learn from you and gather strength from your strength. This thread is an amazing group of women. Lisa
Posts.Title: How are people with liver mets doing? blondie1 JFL

Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2018 02:47PM intothewoods wrote: BlaineJennifer, I agree too. sometimes balls are dropped. I am due to start the next round of Xeloda and just had to chase down my oncology pharmacist to put the order in. I explained that I was leaving for an overseas trip on Monday and wanted to be sure I had the meds. He still seemed lackadaisical saying the pharmacy usually has it in stock but his better self kicked in and he called to double check. Usually he is great and callsearly in the week to see how things are and check the blood work but not this week. If I had to go two weeks without treatment that is small potatoes compared to your six weeks. I have always thought the most important thing is to have faith and trust in your MO. It sounds like you do and he is not really the issue. It's the "stuff happens" with any organiztion that can make cancer so much harder.So sorry to hear about the heart issue. Hugs to you. Raine wells I remember how much more concerned my onc was when the liver mets were discovered and how disconcerting that was. Faslodex was an easy treatment for me and I got about 9 months. I tried adding the Ibrance but my white blood count plummeted and I was still working in an elementary school so we dropped it. Hoping you get a long run on the tratment.

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2016 10:20PM intothewoods wrote: Gina, Cyber hugs to you and Pauline. I have liver and bone mets too and just started on chemo regime of Doxil and Cytoxan which has been very doable so far. I was expecting to just do 4-6 rounds and then back to a hormonal but my onc said it's possible I'll stay on this until it doesn't work and then perhaps weekly taxol. I've wrapped my head around that possibility. Hoping you can take care of yourself and have lots of good support. My wife is having a harder time in some ways than I am. I told her she has to go back to the Cancer Support Community here in LA. There may be one in NYC. Leftfoot, You will be awesome and we are all rooting for you. You will never go wrong with sharing your own story and truth. Please let us know how it goes! Lisa

Posts.Content: May 16, 2015 10:40AM intothewoods wrote: So sorry- I did mean afinitor+aromasin. I also got the impression there is no one right treatment order. My MO tends to be aggressive and not so much the QOL sort. I did read on the afinitor/aromasin thread a post from Toronto, a school principal, that she has minimal SE on A/A and works full time. That was encouraging to me because I'm a full time school principal and I'll need to dump the afinitor if I can't work. Doc said I could just take the aromasin. I said I was worried about burning through my treatment options and he indicated we weren't- that there would be new drugs. We didn't stick to this line of conversation. Unfortunately, that's typical of my MO but I still like him. If anyone knows how to change the thread title please let me know. My brain sometimes...
Posts.Title: faslodex v arimidex/aromasin doc changd mind mid appt. intothewoods HLB

Posts.Content: May 16, 2015 02:49PM intothewoods wrote: Thanks for the responses everyone! As always, it's great to hear others have had similar conversations or questions about treatment decisions. We truly are not at a point yet where we know exactly what is right for each individual cancer but there is hope that we are on the right path with the research. Exbrnxgrl, it's good to connect with you. The end of the school year is a trying time for me . I'm exhausted, there are lots of deadlines and the bittersweet feeling of having made a positive difference and of having fallen short in areas . You were such an early inspiration with your "Life does not end" thread. That's a big reason why I have been not as active here. For one, I recently discovered the great professional chats and learning available on Twitter and was at a "F-cancer" place so was cyber living in the Twitter-spere for awhile. I'm looking forward to vacation too. I hope you have a smooth year end and a restful/productive summer. Best to all and thanks again for the support. Lisa

Posts.Title: ARRGGH, Amy Robach kebab tangandchris

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2014 04:01PM intothewoods wrote: Ditto. Thank you The DivineMrsM. That article is a must read. I was one of the early detection gals. I had a small tumor, stage 1 no node involvement, a mastectomy and a prophylactic rt one. Finished my 5 years of tamoxifen, tumor markers always low even at the time of my new diagnosis. I didn't think recurrence let alone a distant metastais was an issue. Knowledge is power and we all need the reminder to be grateful for each day and enjoy each moment and never become complacent. I was aware of a "bump" on my chest wall and it never occured to me it was a recurrance. Sounds insane but maybe not considering the early detection message.

Posts.Title: May 15 will be 2 years stellaratovsky Aoibheann

Posts.Content: May 31, 2015 10:55AM intothewoods wrote: Dear Torridon, Our situations are very different and yet I also have been thinking of death quite a bit lately. This is all because my mo changed my medication. He wasn't even saying I had progression, just that my one bone met was more active! That my doc wanted to change my treatment alone was a shock to me. I went from "I'm-going-to-sail-along-on-AIs-for-15+-years and be one of the 1-2%," to I'm going to exhaust my treatment options and die soon. I haven't thought that since the first weeks after diagnosis. The change in my outlook was huge. It also heightened my ambivalence about about my profession and doubts about my abilities so that I am struggling with where to focus. This weekend things are starting to shift though. I started reading a couple of professional books that have helped with my attitude towards work. And I changed my signature to include a different quote that is very meaningful to me and more helpful at this time. I hope that as I deal with this for however long I have I can find ways to cope. I hope the experiences and wisdom the ladies have shared will help you feel better soon and I hope we both stop thinking about our deaths and live fully each day. Thinking of you.
